experiences.name: Registan, Samarkand
experiences.description: The Registan (Uzbek: Регистон, Registon) was the heart of the ancient city of Samarkand of the Timurid Empire, now in Uzbekistan. The name Rēgistan (ریگستان) means 'sandy place' or 'desert' in Persian. The Registan was a public square, where people gathered to hear royal proclamations, heralded by blasts on enormous copper pipes called dzharchis — and a place of public executions. It is framed by three madrasahs (Islamic schools) of distinctive Islamic architecture. The square was regarded as the hub of the Timurid Renaissance.

experiences.name: Shah-i-Zinda, Samarkand
experiences.description: Shah-i-Zinda is a necropolis in the north-eastern part of Samarkand, Uzbekistan. The name, meaning 'Living King,' is connected with the legend that Kusam ibn Abbas, a cousin of the Prophet Muhammad, is buried there. The Shah-i-Zinda complex comprises more than twenty buildings from the 11th to the 19th centuries.

experiences.name: Ichan Kala, Khiva
experiences.description: Ichan Kala is the walled inner town of the city of Khiva, Uzbekistan. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The old town retains more than 50 historic monuments and 250 old houses, dating primarily from the 18th or the 19th centuries. Djuma Mosque, for instance, was established in the 10th century and rebuilt in the 18th century, although its celebrated hypostyle hall still retains 112 columns taken from ancient structures.

experiences.name: Aydarkul Lake
experiences.description: Aydarkul is a large endorheic lake in the Kyzylkum Desert in north-central Uzbekistan. It is the sixteenth largest lake in the world by surface area. The lake was formed as a result of the shallow Karakchansay River changing its course and the Dargom Canal, part of the Hanza irrigation system, failing to contain it. Aydarkul is a popular destination for tourists, offering a serene natural environment and opportunities for various water activities.
